Award.AwardTitle: Hydro-ML: Symposium on Big Data Machine Learning in Hydrology and Water Resources; Pennsylvania, May 25-29, 2020
Award.AbstractNarration: Artificial intelligence has the potential to impact every facet of our society. Machine learning, an important component of artificial intelligence, is revolutionizing much of what we do today. Deep learning is a relatively new subset of machine learning that has tremendous potential to improve our capabilities for industrial applications and scientific discovery. The use of artificial intelligence in hydrology, and deep learning in particular, can bring tremendous benefits to society. Hydrologic academics and professionals, however, have not historically taken advantage of artificial intelligence. While there have been some workshops and gathering opportunities for hydrologists interested in deep learning, there have been no dedicated workshops to build a community that can leverage common datasets, methods, and goals. A Machine Learning in Water Workshop (“Hydro-ML”) is proposed to demystify artificial intelligence for a wider audience in hydrology, build dedicated expertise and collaborative potential through training sessions and hackathons. Building a hydrological machine learning community will enable sharing of resources, organization of competitions stimulating an expansion of the field, and encourage collaboration among academics and professionals to solve large challenges. Special attention will be paid to participants' diversity both in terms of gender and race, which has previously been identified as an issue in artificial intelligence and hydrology. The topics covered by the symposium will be defined through solicitations to the community at large, with the intention of stimulating broader impacts in the hydrologic community. <br/><br/>The Hydro-ML symposium will build a collaborative community focusing on machine learning in hydrology. It will consist of four types of sessions: research presentations, breakout discussion forums, deep learning tutorials and hackathons, and community-building activities. Specific sessions will discuss forward-looking, overarching questions that will be solicited from the participants prior to the meeting. These symposium activities will provide the foundation to build collective efforts in novel dataset identification, preparations for machine learning-in-hydrology competitions, and discussion of physically-informed machine learning. The symposium will be widely advertised through diverse channels, including hydrology newsletters and mailing lists, targeted communications to underrepresented, non-profit, and industry groups, and publications aimed at the general public. The organizing committee will encourage participation from diverse and underrepresented communities, and welcome those who are new to artificial intelligence. The outcomes from the symposium include collective publications serving as positional statements by the community (including journal papers and white papers), detailed plans for hydrologic machine learning competitions, and technical deep learning tutorials for audience with varied deep learning experience, ranging from newcomers to intermediate users. The symposium’s events will be aimed at building a diverse community that enables advancements in hydrology which will benefit society.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in the HydroML Symposium on big data machine learning in hydrology and water resources. Initially planned to occur in May 2020, the Covid pandemic resulted in the delay of the symposium until May of 2022, and expansion from an in-person event to a hybrid format for attendance that enabled both in-person and virtual attendees. The hybrid workshop was held May 18-20, 2022 at the Pennsylvania State University.

The primary goals of the symposium were to emphasize building a community that has common goals and shared resources, de-mystify DL for those new to the field, build up machine learning expertise, encourage collaboration between those already involved, and build a DL community and organization for all participants. The symposium was designed to encourage newcomers to DL, especially those from backgrounds which are underrepresented in hydrology.

 

There were 192 registrants, with 111 of them in person (57 students), and 81 of them attending virtually (34 students). The platform gather.town was used for virtual attendees to enable poster presentations and other interactions, while the plenary and breakout sessions were shared via Zoom (links accessed via gather.town).

72 students and early career researchers applied for financial support to attend the symposium. A rubric was developed to score these applicants based on the information they provided (including diversity criteria). The evaluation was done by a committee served by both senior and junior committee members, and 29 students were granted travel funding plus registration fees covered, while another 16 were offered coverage of registration fees.

There were 67 research presentations spread across 3 plenary sessions with both longer (25 minute) and shorter (5 minute lightning) talks along with panel discussions, and 8 breakout sessions (15 minute talks plus panel discussions). There were also 2 tutorial sessions, along with a poster session in which every attendee was encouraged to participate.

After the symposium, 62 attendees responded to a survey (49 attended in person, 11 attended virtually, and 2 registered for attendance in person but had to change to virtual attendance at the last moment. 100% of all respondents said if the symposium was repeated, they would attend again (53 in person or virtually, 9 in person only, none only virtually or would not attend), and would recommend it to other colleagues (56 in person or virtually, 6 in person only, none only virtually or would not attend). 

At least one journal paper resulted from the symposium, which was published as a perspective paper with 31 authors in Nature Reviews Earth & Environment. The paper is titled "Differentiable modelling to unify machine learning and physical models for geosciences" and uses examples from the hydrology community (who were gathered at the HydroML Symposium) to discuss an emerging genre in modeling that is applicable not only for hydrology, but for many Geoscience disciplines. https://www.nature.com/articles/s43017-023-00450-9

Dipankar Dwivedi from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL) chaired a follow-up symposium, HydroML 2.0, held May 22-24 2023 in Berkeley, CA, supported by the ExaSheds project and Earth and Environmental Sciences at LBNL with 105 in-person and 40 virtual participants (https://eesa.lbl.gov/hydroml-2-0-symposium-inspiring-connections-and-collective-learning-at-berkeley-lab/). Multiple groups have indicated interest in hosting a third HydroML symposium in 2024, and a special issue in Geophysical Research Letters for publication of work presented by HydroML participants is in progress.
